div.p: SIDERIA, in natural hiſtory, the name of a genus of cryſtals, uſed to expreſs thoſe altered in their figure by particles of iron. Theſe are of a rhomboidal figure, and compoſed only of six planes. Of this genus there are four known ſpecies. 1. A colourleſs, pellucid, and thin one ; found in conſiderable quantities among the iron ores of the foreſt of Dean in Glouceſterſhire, and in ſeveral other places. 2. A dull, thick, and brown one; not uncommon in the same places with the former. And, 3. A black and very gloſſy kind, a foſſil of great beauty ; found in the ſame place with the others, as also in Leiceſterſhire and Suſſex.
